facts.text: Appeal by special leave by Ardeshir H. Bhiwandiwala against order of Bombay High Court allowing State appeal against acquittal under s.92 of Factories Act, 1948 for working Wadia Mahal Salt Works without licence under s.6 read with r.4.

Wadia Mahal Salt Works at Wadala, Bombay, extends over 250 acres, consists of temporary shelters for labour and office, pucca platforms for water pump, open area with bunds on sea side to prevent flooding.
Ten or more workers working on any day of preceding twelve months, some work at night, women workers employed, workers need rest, food at mid-day, drinking water, first-aid.

Process at Salt Works: Sea water taken into reservoirs at high tide via sluice gates or pump, divided into compartments for brine of different densities, evaporated by solar energy in crystallizing pans prepared by thumping mud, watched for density, scraped, collected, graded by sieving, bagged.
Labourers' work intermittent: admitting sea water (sometimes night), filling beds, watching density, preventing contamination, scraping/collecting crystals, grading, bagging.
Trial court acquitted appellant holding Salt Works not factory.
Bombay High Court allowed State appeal, convicted appellant.
Chief Inspector of Factories initially considered salt pans factories but later doubted unless equipped with building used in manufacture.
Salt Merchants Association represented for exemption but not that salt works not factory.
Appellant's reply to Inspector dated April 9, 1952, considered Act redundant, not that not factory.

legal_issues.text: Whether Salt Works comes within definition of 'factory' under cl.(m) s.2 of Factories Act, 1948, depending on meaning of 'premises' and whether conversion of sea water into salt crystals is 'manufacturing process' under cl.(k) s.2.

petitioner_arguments.text: 'Premises' in s.2(m) means buildings, not open land; temporary sheds not sufficient; no precincts for open land.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Dictionary meanings; s.2(m) 'premises including precincts'; cited Kent v. Astley, Redgrave v. Lee, Nash v. Hollinshead

petitioner_arguments.text: Conversion of sea water to salt not 'manufacturing process' under s.2(k); merely natural forces of gravity and solar energy, no human agency in conversion.
Provisions of Act not applicable to open salt works; would lead to ludicrous results.

respondent_arguments.text: Salt Works is factory; 'premises' includes open land; salt making involves human agency aided by natural forces, constitutes manufacturing process.

court_reasoning.text: 'Premises' is generic term including open land, land with buildings or buildings alone; 'including precincts' enlarges scope; internal evidence in Act (s.7(1)(bb), s.93, s.85) shows not restricted to buildings; welfare of workers irrespective of location.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not intend to discriminate between workers in buildings vs open land.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished English cases (Kent v. Astley etc.) as based on historical Factory Acts limited to mills/buildings; later Acts include open premises; Factories Act 1937 explicitly includes open air.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No building required for factory under 1948 Act.

court_reasoning.text: Conversion of sea water to salt is manufacturing process: human agency (sluice gates, filling, watching, scraping etc.) treats/adapts sea water (non-commercial) into salt (commercial) for sale; aided by natural forces.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Processes fit s.2(k): treating/adapting substance for use/sale.

court_reasoning.text: Cited precedents like Sedgwick v. Watney (beer bottling), State of Kerala v. V.M. Patel (pepper/ginger) support treatment/adaptation as manufacturing process.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Finished article (salt) different from input (brine/sea water).

court_reasoning.text: Administrative opinions (Chief Inspector) and prior representations not determinative; first contention of not factory raised in trial court.

holdings.text: Salt Works comes within 'premises' in definition of 'factory' under s.2(m) even if open land.
Process of converting sea water into salt is 'manufacturing process' under s.2(k).
Appellant rightly convicted under s.92 for operating without licence.

precedents_cited.relevance: Slate quarry open air not factory under 1867 Act; historical context limited to mills.
Followed Kent; open quarry not factory.
Farm grinding meal for own stock not factory; ludicrous results argument rejected here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sedgwick v. Watney Combe, Reid & Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Treatment changing unmarketable beer to bottled marketable beer is process.

precedents_cited.case_name: Grove v. Lloyds British Testing Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Adapting for sale makes article different.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kaye v. Burrows and Hines v. Eastern Counties Farmers Co-operative Association Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Processes making finished article different from input is adaptation for sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Kerala v. V.M. Patel
precedents_cited.relevance: Winnowing, cleaning, washing, drying pepper/ginger is manufacturing process.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Chinniah, Manager, Sangu Soap Works

statutes_cited.name: Factories Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Definition of factory (premises where manufacturing process carried on); licensing; applied to salt works.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Bombay High Court order convicting appellant under s.92 Factories Act for operating Salt Works without licence, holding it a factory as premises where manufacturing process carried on.

key_quotes.text: 'Premises' is a generic term meaning open land or land with buildings or buildings alone.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The conversion of sea water into salt is not due merely to natural forces, but is due to human efforts aided by natural forces.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes human agency in manufacturing process.

key_quotes.text: The Act is for the welfare of the workers... the legislature could not have intended to discriminate between the workers who are engaged in a manufacturing process in a building and those who are engaged in such a process on open land.
key_quotes.speaker: court
